title: 'Tech companies will do well' amid coronavirus pandemic: expert
content:
All major indices are moving higher Thursday around the opening bell as earnings season continues and jobless claims reach more than 26 million over the past few weeks. Noah Hamman, AdvisorShares CEO joins Yahoo Finance to discuss.

Video Transcript

BRIAN SOZZI: Let's stay on the markets here with Noah Hamman, CEO of Advisor Shares. Noah, always good to see you. Give us some positive news. Give us a good trade to be making in this-- not us, but viewers-- a good trade to making this environment. The initial jobless claims data wasn't good, had new home sales data just hitting tape. That's not good either. What should investors be gravitating to?

NOAH HAMMAN: I think probably getting hedged. It's the same message from last time. I know it's probably not the news that people want to hear, but I would be hedging myself in this marketplace. There's still a lot of uncertainty. There's an outstanding number of people that are not working right now. The number is just a pile-on from the previous numbers. I think the total now is somewhere close to 25 million people out of jobs. And so the numbers aren't great.

You've got to look at something like a HDGE or a DWSH. They're two short equity ETFs that can actually add some performance to your portfolio, probably not today. It looks like the markets are heading up, which is terrific, but I think over the course of this year, they're going to add some value to your portfolio.

ALEXIS CHRISTOFOROUS: But Noah, you actually point out that it's really important for investors to be careful they're using the right ETF to hedge their portfolio. What's the criteria here in this environment for the right ETF?

NOAH HAMMAN: It's just understanding what the ETF does, right? So we've seen the news this week with the USO ETF and people kind of understanding that hey, this isn't following the price of oil. It's following the price of this futures contract that then that, in and of itself, went sort of crazy. And we run into the same thing, having alternative investment strategies in our lineup, like the two products I mentioned that are short equity strategies, there are some products out there that are called inverse funds. They're passively managed.

Story continues

They just provide the inverse of an index, but they only do it for a day. And so the product sponsors are great about articulating that, but investors, you know, similar to probably what we saw with the USO ETF, don't maybe always understand what that means. And so if you are hedging over a market cycle because you think it's going to be bad for a while, you want to be careful of those products.

And just as an example with some numbers, the inverse-- single-data inverse, passively managed ETF with the ticker symbol SH, I believe is up-- let me look at the numbers-- 8.37. And this is as of-- this is year-to-date through April 21, but the market's down 13%. Some investors-- not all-- think that that fund should be up 13%, and it's not. And it's because of its daily investment objective.

So short funds like DWSH or Hedge, for example, over the same time frame are up upwards of-- I think HDGE is up 23.18%, and DWSH is up 35% just this year to date. So understanding the difference, if you're the type of investor to HDGE, and you always want to be careful and know what you're investing in, but understanding those differences are critical.

BRIAN SOZZI: Yeah, just a quick follow-up, March new home sales down 15.4% month over month, just stunning data we continue to get from the US economy. Noah, what is-- we're in the eye of a storm of earnings season. What are some of your takeaways so far?

NOAH HAMMAN: Well, the target numbers were incredibly impressive this morning, right? In some ways, not surprising as we think about who's benefiting and what companies and sectors are benefiting in this environment. But I think, you know, more pain for longer, unfortunately, between the unemployment numbers, not surprising to see lower housing start numbers.

You know, maybe there's some value to be found in the energy space, even though we're mostly short some of those equity positions. But maybe there's some opportunities there as things start to turn around a little bit. And I think that's the important thing. I'm so optimistic that the economy is going to turn around. It doesn't actually mean that the stock market's going to follow along with it.

ALEXIS CHRISTOFOROUS: And Noah, you know, I just want to bring to your attention and to our viewers' attention to the latest economic report showing a record drop in business activity, and according to IHS Markit. And this, of course, is consistent with figures we're seeing come out of Germany and Japan, Australia indicating a worldwide recession. For those who don't want to play in equities right now, US or otherwise, where should they put their money, or do they just sit on some cash at the moment?

NOAH HAMMAN: I would go cash. Or I think that one of the things we talked about last time, which I think is still a good position, which is probably a longer maturity treasuries. I don't think interest rates are going to be heading up anytime soon. And in fact, there still could be more downward pressure. You want to be in a safe type of investment, treasuries are there. But given where I think interest rates might be going, you can actually see some total return or some capital appreciation with that allocation.

And it's not, you know, sell everything and forget about it, right? There is a portion of my portfolio that is for the very, very long term, for my retirement, which is hopefully out in the future sometime, but that I'm not getting too aggressive on. I'm still dollar-cost averaging. But if you have the ability to protect yourself and/or you're looking for places to put new money today, you want to be defensive. Either get hedged or look at cash or look at longer-- long-- longer-term dated treasuries.

BRIAN SOZZI: Yeah, no retiring yet, Noah. We still need your market insights. Don't leave us so quickly, all right?

NOAH HAMMAN: Thank you, I appreciate it.

BRIAN SOZZI: How do you play-- you're the ETF master here. How do you play rising bankruptcies in the US? I'm worried about retail. I'm worried about a lot of industrial companies, also worried a lot about US-focused small businesses.

NOAH HAMMAN: Right, it's a tough one. I think, you know, shorting is the way to do it. Getting out of the way with cash is the way to do it. There's actually not a lot of investment options in terms of, say, inverse credit. Those are very difficult products to build because in the times where things are good, the decay, with the interest payments, can make those products very challenging. So I think you're only places to go, you know, are probably-- well, and big blue chips, right? Hang out there.

The target numbers, I would look at that. When I think things are going to start to turn, it'll bring the blue chips back up. And like we saw early in the cycle where the smaller caps and the micro-caps were the first to indicate there's problems ahead, they'll be the last then to turn. So I would just stay in high-quality equities. If I have to be in the market, I would go to cash, treasuries. Or if you're comfortable, shorting the market can provide some positive returns, maybe in a small allocation in your portfolio.

ALEXIS CHRISTOFOROUS: Noah, we talked before about the energy sector, not doing what it's doing right now, I mean, an unprecedented cratering for the oil markets. But I know you don't have a lot of exposure in that space, but what do you have right now, and are you holding it, given this unprecedented drop in oil prices?

NOAH HAMMAN: Sure, so I think Chevron is the name that I just saw come up in the double-line equity. It's a value ETF strategy. They have a small allocation to energy. They're under weighted compared to their benchmark of the Russell 1000 value, but they are picking and choosing some companies in there that they think could be the beneficiary of a change in those oil prices.

So-- and I think that's, in general, where we are. And I'm biased when I say this because all of our strategies are actively managed, but this really should be the environment for active managers to shine. You can find those opportunities even in a tough sector like energy. You just got to be stock selective and have some very good insight in those companies.

BRIAN SOZZI: Noah, one thing that has caught my attention, I got a note from one of my friends this morning, the NASDAQ 100 to S&P 500 ratio is at its highest level since 2000, the dot-com bubble. Are we seeing some kind of bubble in tech stocks, and does that surprise you?

NOAH HAMMAN: Well, you're definitely seeing them being a bit more defensive in this market. It probably doesn't surprise me, you know, no different than seeing online sales for Target go up dramatically. You're seeing some of the numbers you saw from Netflix the other day. It feels like in this, you know, current, not fair to say post-pandemic world yet, I think the tech companies are going to do well.

Look at what's happened with Zoom stock, and look at the aggressive moves that Microsoft with Teams and even Google is making with their own Meeting software, seeing that this isn't going to probably slow down any time soon. So I don't-- you know, it's-- they haven't tracked or declined as much as the regular-- the rest of the equity space.

But I don't know that I would call the tech space a bubble just yet. I mean, overall market decline, sure, but I think they're going to weather it probably better than others, certainly the retailing and consumer cyclical space, things like that that are I think absolutely going to underperform the rest of the year.

BRIAN SOZZI: All right, let's leave it there, Noah Hamman, CEO of Adviser Shares. I will reiterate, no retiring.

NOAH HAMMAN: Thank you, I appreciate it.

title: Wall Street bullish on Netflix following Q1 results, but concerns linger
content:
A slew of Wall Street analysts reacted to Netflix’s first quarter results, with most still bullish on the stock. As of Tuesday, it had a consensus rating of 29 buys, 8 holds, 6 sells, with an average price target of $428.07, although a few analysts expressed concerns over a strong dollar, retention and pricing.

Video Transcript

MYLES UDLAND: Let's take a look at shares of Netflix right now. That stock is off right around 2 and 1/2% following its latest quarterly report published last night. And let's take a look in our Call of the Day at two separate notes on the stock. We've got Piper Sandler raising their price target to $500 per share, maintaining an overweight rating. Meanwhile, Stifel lowering their outlook for the stock, decreasing their rating to hold from a buy.

So, Dan Roberts, last night, we saw Netflix essentially, you know, post double the number of subscriber gains that the company had-- that Wall Street had forecasted, and I think the debate here kind of splits pretty cleanly along two lines. One, this is great for Netflix, everyone's watching it. Or two, they're pulling forward any demand that they were going to enjoy kind of smoothly over-- over the years to come.

DAN ROBERTS: Yeah, I'm with Piper on this debate, Myles, because, you know, the pull forward argument is one that we just discussed Monday of this week on this show about Peloton, the fear that, oh, times look good right now, but we're worried about the back half of the year and-- and once we emerge from coronavirus. I understand the thinking of, you know, wanting to see that the company is putting its house in order for when we get through this. But again-- and I said this about Peloton-- it's a good problem to have.

I mean, there are companies that are struggling right now and will thus be struggling also when this time ends. And so in contrast with those, it seems to me pretty good news if you are seeing a lot of additions right now. I know that, you know, there was an-- an Ever quarter note that said this is probably peak net additions, to bring in a third analyst note into our discussion. This is probably going to be, you know, peak Netflix net additions in a quarter, and it's anyone's guess. I think that's kind of a big call to make.

Story continues

You know, more anecdotally, I would also add, on this show we've talked often about the idea that, you know, as more and more competition comes around and other great original shows are going to be on other platforms, is Netflix really as dominant a king in the next year or two? Is it going to still kind of wear the crown? And anecdotally, I think yes, and it's because of the kitchen sink. I mean, I'll use myself as an example. Just last night, we were on Netflix and we were looking at the home page, and I saw the show "Waco," which I know you watched when it was a Paramount exclusive, with Taylor Kitsch from "Friday Night Lights."

And I remember wanting to watch that show, but not having the Paramount service. Well, lo and behold, it has made its way to Netflix, which is always a nice thing to see. I mean, the-- the platform is always getting more content. And I also saw on my homepage recommend to me that "Wild, Wild Country" documentary, which I remember people buzzing about months and months ago, and I didn't watch it at the time. And I thought, oh, another thing for me to add to my watchlist.

My point being, you know, people say, well, now that I've seen "Ozark" and I've done "Stranger Things" and I've done "Breaking Bad," and I don't know if there's so much that's exciting and new on Netflix. It doesn't need to be all new shows. It's always adding stuff, and there's always stuff to discover on there. And I just think-- I have a hard time believing that all the people who've newly added Netflix during coronavirus will cut it when the economy reopens.

MYLES UDLAND: Yeah, Jen, let me tell you, I mean, you know, cults and David Koresh, that is the kind of pandemic viewing that I know I'm interested in.

JEN ROGERS: Yeah, I mean, look, I don't want to be too flip, but let's get to the Stifle note. If you were a Hollywood writer and you needed to write the perfect scenario for a streaming company to do well, this is it. This is, the-- the note from Stifle, as good as it gets. We're all trapped in our homes, OK? And they still have-- do not have free cash flow. They adjusted their guidance for free cash flow to be a billion. That's better than they're-- expected, but it's because they've halted production. I mean, they still are not free cash flow positive. And what could be better than having everybody trapped in your house?

MELODY HAHM: Yeah, and just to that point, Jen, I-- I do want to note that Reed Hastings mentioned yesterday that production has actually resumed in South Korea and Iceland, with plans to reopen certain projects around the world. And then on that advertising side of things, when we think about all the other platforms where there's the premium service or the free service or the in-betweens that offer minimal ads, I think we've-- we've talked to a lot of analysts and we've heard a lot of chatter, right, leading up into the pandemic that Netflix needs to add that model, needs to offer multiple tiers in order to gain more revenue.

But I think this is one of those instances where they're so well-positioned, regardless of the shrinking budgets of every single company around the world to invest in marketing and ad spend, Netflix is fine, right? And they have so much backlog of a lot of content. And to Dan's point, they have so many licensing deals in the works that the likes of Quibi and even Disney have not been necessarily able to forge. So yeah, being an incumbent in this space definitely helps during this time.

MYLES UDLAND: But to that point, Melody, I saw that-- that commentary from Netflix, and I was-- I'm a little skeptical that their production schedule is totally fine. And-- and I think that they-- they maybe can paper over some of that because of the backlog that we've discussed. Whereas, you know, Disney puts a movie in the theaters, it either moves the theater window or it doesn't. I feel like Netflix is going to be able to say that nothing changed when really things probably did.

MELODY HAHM: Yeah, and we know that just by that $100 million fund that they created to help their own employees, to help the entertainment industry here in LA as well. But I think in terms of positioning among all of its counterparts, there certainly is that expediency or that ability to short circuit some of the lag time perhaps that a brand new player was-- would necessarily be facing right now.

JEN ROGERS: And just real quick on the Stifle note, since they were the bear case, I mean, Netflix is a great business. Even-- even they like it, they like it at 300. That's it.

MYLES UDLAND: Right. Stock was at a record high last night briefly, so you have to like it a lot, I guess. We'll leave it-- we'll leave it with that. We'll leave it at that.

title: 'Tiger King' or 'Love Is Blind'? Here are the shows Netflix's Co-Founder is binging
content:
Marc Randolph, Netflix Co-Founder and “That Will Never Work” author, joins Yahoo Finance’s Zack Guzman to discuss which shows he’s been watching while staying at home during the coronavirus.

Video Transcript

ZACK GUZMAN: And I don't want to end our discussion with you, since it's been so long since we chatted, on a negative note here.

MARC RANDOLPH: Thank you.

ZACK GUZMAN: I always get yelled at every time we have you on and I don't ask this question, because we are of course, spending a lot of time at home-- in terms of passing the time right now, when it comes to what you're watching as the co-founder of Netflix, who apparently also and Disney Plus, what is it that you're turning to, Marc, during these times?

MARC RANDOLPH: Well, Zack, the thing is, my watching is going way up. And of course, we burned through Tiger King-- of course, spectacular. All right. I'll admit it-- I did watch Love is Blind and thought that was pretty great as well.

We're almost to the season finale of Ozark. But the thing that I'm kind of most amazed at is, I'm finally watching the show which is the most popular show outside the United States. Do you know what that is?

ZACK GUZMAN: [NO SPEECH] Is that the one you're talking about?

MARC RANDOLPH: That's the one. And I go, I probably should watch this show. And it's actually surprisingly good. A little soap opera-y. But it's actually pretty compelling.

ZACK GUZMAN: Yes, Money Heist, for those English speakers out there as well. I noticed they changed the title. But I'm right there with you. I'm not ashamed to admit it. I watched Love is Blind as well. Very interesting content choices being made out there at Netflix.

But Marc, thank you so much for joining us, man. Always enjoy our discussions. The co-founder of Netflix, as well as the author of the book That Will Never Work-- thanks so much for chatting with us, man.

MARC RANDOLPH: Thanks, Zack. A pleasure.

title: Netflix co-founder: I’m "very impressed" with Disney+
content:
Marc Randolph, Netflix Co-Founder and “That Will Never Work” author, joins Yahoo Finance’s Zack Guzman to discuss Netflix's jump in subscribers amid the coronavirus outbreak, along with his thoughts on competitors like Disney+.

Video Transcript

ZACK GUZMAN: Now, we're also keeping our eyes on Netflix shares, off just slightly, off about 3% despite the overall rally we're seeing in the market right now. Of course, the streaming giant reported earnings yesterday, and revenue came in mostly in line with expectations. Earnings per share was off just slightly due to currency effects there off of a stronger dollar.

But the big takeaway was that Netflix added an impressive record 15.7 million subscribers across the globe, that a high watermark for Netflix. And for more on the quarter and the way that it's navigating the benefit here from a lot of people staying at home, I want to bring on the co-founder of Netflix, Marc Randolph, also the first CEO of Netflix as well, before Reed Hastings took over, and the author of "That Will Never Work." He joins us now.

Marc, it's good to see you again. When we look at the quarter, obviously, clearly, we heard on the earnings call that they did catch a benefit from more people in lockdown mode, staying at home, turning to Netflix, to streaming these things. What's your take on I guess that trend and how it could maybe we could see that even off, as we move along here in the year?

MARC RANDOLPH: Well, listen, first of all, I've got to start by crowing a little bit about this accomplishment and having this level of subscribers. I mean, you have to keep in mind that we started this subscription business almost 20 years ago. And back then, our analytics were pretty weak, so we only got these subscriber numbers once a week. And I remember, it was like a teenager waiting to see his Instagram likes come through, just waiting to see what these numbers were.

You know, I've even got framed in my office the print out of hitting 500,000 subscribers. But it took us 10 plus years to hit 16 million total, and Netflix hit that in a single quarter. So what is it 183, 182 million total paid subscribers? These numbers just absolutely remarkable, but you know, the thing is-- and you probably picked this up from the earnings call-- is that, you know, they were very, very cautious about saying that these were most likely one-time-effect numbers.

Story continues

And in fact, even more cautionary that these probably reflected numbers being pulled in from future quarters. And here's the real insight that I took away from listening to the earnings call yesterday is they used the word guess. Reed was saying, this is a guess. There's lots of guesswork here, and in 25 years of working with Reed and watching Reed, I have to tell you, he does not use the words guess and guesswork lightly. And I think that really fundamentally is a reflection on the times, is that we really don't know what the future holds, not just for Netflix but for business as a whole.

ZACK GUZMAN: Yeah, but I mean, at least he did give, I mean, we've seen so many companies cut guidelines and estimates. At least he was sticking with something to give investors there when we look forward, but there was also a couple other things there. When you looked into the numbers itself, of course, Netflix has been spending a lot on its content. That has been the case for quite some time.

When you think about the numbers that they spend to, I believe it was, RBO Capital Markets looking at-- or BMO Capital Markets looking at how much they could spend. They'd spent about $15 billion for content last year, could top $17 billion, according to them, this year, but on a cash burn basis, $3 billion has been historically what Netflix has been burning per year. They said that number could drop to $1 billion this year.

So I mean, when you think about how much money is going into the content side here to keep up, especially as we have a whole bunch of entrants, I'd be curious to know what you're watching at your own home too. Is it Disney Plus is out there now, and you've got Peacock coming too. I mean, what's your idea here, and what do you make of the way that they continue to spend on content and as it gets more competitive?

MARC RANDOLPH: You know, well, certainly, Netflix is staking its future on its content, and they're certainly spending commensurate with the size of their audience and commensurate with the fact that they are in the clear, dominant leadership position. I mean, even with the announcement of suspension of production in so many places, you know, Netflix announced yesterday that, in fact, they pretty much had 2020 in the can. And so these delays are going to be pushed out to 2021, but it's going to be faced by every single streaming service at the same time.

But you know, I'm not overly worried about the size of the spend. I mean, especially if you look at its commensurate with subscriber growth. And I think it really is a dominant thing for them to be able to outspend so dramatically players like Disney and players like Apple and Prime.

ZACK GUZMAN: Yeah, and I mean, you mentioned Reed Hastings, and I know you guys you documented your relationship with him in the book "That Will Never Work." I loved reading about how you guys operated together in the early days. He did have a lot of praise though for one competitor, Disney Plus, on the earnings call. I just want to play what he had to say about their growth so far and then get your reaction on the other side. Here's what he said.

REED HASTINGS: You know, I've been so impressed with the Disney Plus execution. You know, over 20 years of watching different businesses, incumbents, like Blockbuster and Walmart and all of these companies, I've never seen such a good execution, you know, of the incumbent learning the new way and mastering it.

ZACK GUZMAN: He's there. You know him. I mean, what are your thoughts on the way that he's not necessarily fearful of the competition here and actually giving praise to Disney?

MARC RANDOLPH: Well, I must echo. I've got to echo what he's saying, is I'm actually very impressed with the job that Disney has done. I mean, even from the moment that I first signed up for that service, I said, wow, the real fit and finish here is pretty superb. And it hasn't diminished, and they certainly have really blown a lot of people away by hitting 50 million subscribers in six months. That's probably years ahead of what the schedule was.

But you know, despite Disney's success, it's really hard to build in two years something Netflix has been working on for 22 years. I mean, there are certain advantages to having 180 plus million subscribers and all the data that comes with that direct relationship. You have this history of remarkable execution, and you really have what I consider the secret weapon which is focus.

You know, Netflix is not worrying about theatrical releases. It's not worried about theme parks. It's not worried about cruise lines. It's not worried about live sports. There's a certain advantage to being in some ways a pure play. And we haven't even mentioned the amazing fact that, a few days ago, Netflix passed Disney in market cap, which I never in a million years could have seen coming.

ZACK GUZMAN: Yeah, and I mean, I'm sure it's kind of crazy to watch, you know, this baby that you helped create back then and were the first CEO of back then. And seeing how fast it's grown here to become the leader in the space, when you think about the streaming space back, when you were sending DVDs in the mail. But when you look at it too, it's interesting, because this is the first time, of course, Netflix will be navigating in what is pretty much guaranteed to be recession territory here, when we look at it, maybe since, you know, since the Great Recession we saw back in 2009. But when you look at it, is there truth in your mind to the idea that it is kind of a recession-proof stock here, recession proof company. As it is kind of, I guess you can make the case, replacement for going to theaters, as more Americans are kind of afraid of doing just that.

MARC RANDOLPH: I think certainly the events we've seen in the last few months have driven a lot of people to watch a lot more television, and that certainly does help a company like Netflix, as it helps all of the streaming providers. But I think, fundamentally, this is a much longer term play. I mean, what we're seeing is the fact that internet TV is the future, and the people who are really taking it on the chin is linear TV.

And we're going to see all of these companies have a long future, and yes, it'll be rocky. It'll be uncertain. There'll be a lot of volatility over the next 12 months, as the coronavirus shakes itself out. But fundamentally, long term, this is all about the migration from linear to internet TV and whether Netflix can maintain its commanding market share as that builds out, and I'm personally pretty confident that it can.

ZACK GUZMAN: Yeah. All right, and even despite the fact that you've been a big fan of Disney Plus as well and what they have built there, it sounds like a subscriber to them as well.

MARC RANDOLPH: Well, you know, it's an amazing time to be a consumer. You know, just a couple weeks ago, we had Quibi coming out. We had Peacock doing their soft launch. We have HBO Max coming out next month.

I mean, it's pretty remarkable to see all these options for us as consumers, and I think, quite frankly, it's a great thing for all these companies, because it keeps everyone on their toes. I think one of the reasons that Disney is doing so well and executing so clearly is because they know they have to. This is by no means a layup, and I think, ultimately, it's going to keep Netflix on its toes too.

title: 'The way we work has been changed forever' amid Coronavirus outbreak: PagerDuty CEO
content:
PagerDuty, a cloud-computing tech company, is partnering with many on-demand digital brands including Netflix, Peloton and Zoom as many across the globe work from home. Jennifer Tejada, PagerDuty CEO, joins Yahoo Finance to discuss their partnerships and how the coronavirus pandemic may impact the future of the workforce.

Video Transcript

BRIAN SOZZI: There's is one tech company out there whose platform is insuring your work-from-home life goes as smoothly as possible. That will be PagerDuty. Here with us now is PagerDuty CEO Jennifer Tejada. Jennifer, good to finally speak with you. Thanks for taking a few minutes this morning. How exactly is PagerDuty playing in this whole work-from-home movement that we're all experiencing right now?

JENNIFER TEJADA: Good morning. Well, thank you so much for having me, Brian and Alexis. It's nice to see you, PagerDuty is basically supporting an invisible front line, the IT teams that sit behind all of your favorite on-demand digital brands that you're-- you're engaging with now that you've had this societal shift and the change we work, in the change in the way we work and we live.

So as your home doing your work also on Peloton. You're ordering stretchy pants from Lululemon because it's all about the-- you know, the work-from-home pants. You're leveraging your e-commerce websites, whether it's Home Depot or others because you're nesting around at home. They're see-- all these companies, they're seeing a dramatic surge in interest and engagement in their web and mobile apps. And PagerDuty helps IT teams ensure that everything's working the way it's supposed to and the right person gets orchestrated to the right opportunity or problem in-- in real time and at the right time.

And we do that through automation and machine learning. What's been really interesting is for most of our customers, where, like I said, some of the biggest brands that you would recognize-- we serve nearly 60% of the Fortune 100. Most of these teams have been sent home. So they're no longer sitting together in a network operating center, where they can talk amongst each other, solve these problems as they come up. And in some cases, some of these industries are seeing 10, 11 times the number of incidents that they saw-- than they saw before COVID-19 because people are online more hours of the day more frequently, looking for those services, whether it's entertainment or on-demand delivery to their homes.

Story continues

ALEXIS CHRISTOFOROUS: Jennifer, how is all of this going to change our workplace when-- when we're-- when the pandemic is behind us? And what role do you see PagerDuty playing in all of that?

JENNIFER TEJADA: It's a great question. I think the way we work has been changed forever. I think our employees who have been working from home since March 9 have really experienced an increased efficiency and frankly a deeper one-on-one connection with their team members because you're seeing people face to face in Zoom or whatever conferencing solution that you're using. And that means that you actually can connect in a way differently than you would conference room to conference room or with people who were remote while you're in the office.

And so that connection's become, I think, really important. The efficiency of meetings has really improved. The fact that people are gaining time not having to commute is a big benefit.

But it also means that you've got to leverage modern interoperable tools so that you can work effectively at home. You're no longer sitting next to a service or your IT team in the office. And that means that IT teams around the world have been under pressure to deliver laptops, to make sure VPNs are up and running, to make sure their employees have Wi-Fi access. And PagerDuty is supporting those distributed teams as they-- as they do that in many ways.

We've also seen a change in how PagerDuty's been leveraged by executives and leadership teams for crisis management. So I can point to examples in the health care industry, where health care companies are using PagerDuty to get access to health care workers when they see a surge in patient demand, or where they're trying to virtualize their telemedicine services, where they've physically seen people in their bricks-and-mortar practice.

And we're also seeing large online retailers that are using PagerDuty for things like alerting their crisis management team when someone in their warehouse demonstrates signs of ill health, so very quickly get those people care. And so, again, it's-- it's the virtualization of getting the right person on the right problem in the right moment, no matter where they are in the business.

BRIAN SOZZI: All right, Jennifer Tejada, PagerDuty CEO, thanks for joining us. And thank you for keeping my Peloton workouts going. It's been-- it's been a tough month and a half.

JENNIFER TEJADA: My absolute pleasure. They are a great partner. And I hope we all come back to the office fit.

BRIAN SOZZI: So true. All right, thanks, Jen.

content:

title: Delta, AT&T earnings: What to know in markets Wednesday
content:
Earnings from Delta Air Lines (DAL) and AT&T (T) will take center stage Wednesday.

The airline industry has been one of the hardest hit amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Travel demand got hammered over recent months and major U.S. airlines have had to slash capacity in an attempt to preserve cash. Investors will be focusing on commentary from Delta’s management Wednesday morning for any updates on how the company is dealing with the ongoing pandemic.

Delta is expected to report an adjusted loss per share of 87 cents on $9.19 billion in revenue during Q1. On April 4, Delta said that it was burning through $60 million of cash per day and expected second-quarter revenue to fall 90%. Much like the rest of the companies reporting this earnings season, Delta’s big picture and guidance will matter more much than the company’s financial results during the previous quarter.

UBS pointed out that “For 2020, after factoring in the 70% grant as part of the CARES act, DAL will have about $21 billion in total debt and $4.2 billion in cash and short-term investments.” Katja Herbers arives for the Premiere Of HBO's "Westworld" Season 3 held at TCL Chinese Theatre on March 5, 2020 in Hollywood, California. (Photo by Albert L. Ortega/Getty Images)

Meanwhile, telecom giant AT&T will also deliver first-quarter financial results ahead of the market open. It is expected to report adjusted earnings of 84 cents per share on $43.99 billion in revenue during Q1.

One major point of focus for investors will be on AT&T’s upcoming launch of HBO Max on May 27. If HBO Max launches as scheduled, it would be yet another streaming service looking to cash in during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Tuesday evening, streaming giant Netflix (NFLX) reported that it added 15.8 paid subscribers in the first quarter, exceeding expectations for 8.47 sub additions. Shares hit a record high in after-hours trading. Meanwhile, media powerhouse Disney (DIS) announced earlier this month that its streaming service Disney+ hit 50 million global subscribers shortly after launching in key European markets and India.

With the streaming space getting even more saturated, it will prove crucial for AT&T to deliver a solid plan of action with its prepared launch of HBO Max.

Story continues

Furthermore, any updates from management on AT&T’s previous proposed three-year business plan will be closely watched. AT&T proposed the plan after pressure from activist investor Elliott Management pushed for a board shakeup last fall.

With cord-cutting still on the rise and COVID-19-related cost cutting, investors will also be paying attention to how DirecTV has been faring amid the current environment.

Other notable reports schedule for Wednesday include Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Biogen (BIIB) before market open; O’Reilly Automotive (ORLY), CSX (CSX), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) after market close.

—

Heidi Chung is a reporter at Yahoo Finance. Follow her on Twitter: @heidi_chung.

More from Heidi:

The stock market’s rally is being fueled by these massive stocks Jobless claims: Another 5.245 million Americans file for unemployment benefits ‘The economy is literally in free fall:’ Economist

Find live stock market quotes and the latest business and finance news

Follow Yahoo Finance on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, Flipboard, LinkedIn, and reddit.

title: Best ETFs of 2020: The Global X Cloud Computing Fund Should Be a Winner
content:
This article is a part of InvestorPlace.com’s Best ETFs for 2020 contest. Dana Blankenhorn’s choice for the contest is the Global X Cloud Computing Fund (NASDAQ:CLOU).

Since the start of 2020, the Global X Cloud Computing Fund (NASDAQ:CLOU) is down by 9%. Best ETFs of 2020: The Global X Cloud Computing Fund Should Be a Winner

InvestorPlace - Stock Market News, Stock Advice & Trading Tips

In a market infected with fear thanks to the coronavirus from China, that counts as a win.

CLOU had been outperforming the S&P 500 during January and February. The divergence has sharpened since things got serious on Feb. 19. Since then, CLOU is down 18%, but the S&P is down 27%.

Is This Still One of the Best ETFs to Consider?

CLOU is designed to track the INDXX USA Cloud Computing Index. This index encompasses companies that are actively involved in the cloud computing industry. Most are applications sold as services.

The largest holding of CLOU is Shopify (NYSE:SHOP), an e-commerce application that was one of the market’s best performers in 2018 and 2019. Over the last three years it rose from less than $70 per share to a recent high of almost $600 before falling back to its present level of $415.

Other big application providers in the index are Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX), Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) and Twilio (NYSE:TWLO), the latter of which embeds voice, video and text into other applications.

Many CLOU components provide services for other cloud companies. An example is Zscaler (NASDAQ:ZS), a cloud security company whose shares are up 23% so far in 2020. Zscaler has been warning about risks in the “shadow IoT” world, the laptops and phones used by workers at home.

7 Small-Cap Stocks That Are Not Worth a Second Glance

Not everything CLOU touches has turned to gold. Among the losers so far are Paycom Software (NYSE:PAYC), which provides cloud-based human resources applications. Paycom has been hit hard as companies have moved to lay off workers, and the shares are down 20% so far in 2020.

Story continues

Beyond Applications

CLOU doesn’t just feature cloud application providers.

Akamai Technologies (NASDAQ:AKAM), originally created as a Content Delivery Network in 1998, now offers a host of security and connectivity solutions for carriers. Its software works inside the network, invisible to most users. Its customers include service providers as well as enterprises. Akamai shares are up nearly 3% so far this year.

Another big holding is Digital Realty Trust (NYSE:DLR), a real estate investment trust (REIT) that owns data centers. These are the buildings, filled with computers and networking gear, through which enterprises connect with the cloud and clouds connect to each other. REITs are organized to build with debt and pay income back to shareholders. DLR’s dividend of $4.48 per share last year yielded 3.34%. Since the start of the year, DLR shares are up 13%.

Proofpoint (NASDAQ:PFPT) focuses on protecting e-mail, both the messages themselves and the mailboxes they rest in. This has become the most expensive problem in all of cybercrime, the company says. Since the start of 2020, however, Proofpoint shares are down by 14%, because it has been delaying profits in favor of growth. That’s an approach that is in bad taste right now.

The Bottom Line on CLOU

I had no idea a global pandemic was around the corner when I chose to recommend CLOU late last year.

I was just looking to win the contest. It seemed to me that remote work, and cloud applications, were fated to grow fast. Most CLOU holdings are growth companies, not dividend payers, and that aggressive approach will usually win.

As I wrote at the time, “To win a contest you must be bold.” Even by the end of 2019, the transition to the cloud was only 20% complete, according to International Business Machines (NYSE:IBM).

That puts cloud applications at the center of their growth curve. Such companies have ample pricing power, limited competition and innovative solutions to offer. The way to growth is always on the leading edge.

So, it seems, is the way to safety in a panic.

Dana Blankenhorn has been a financial journalist since 1978. His latest book is Technology’s Big Bang: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow with Moore’s Law, essays on technology available at the Amazon Kindle store. Follow him on Twitter at @danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in DLR.

More From InvestorPlace

America’s Richest ZIP Code Holds Wealth Gap Secret  10 Stocks to Buy That Will Benefit From Coronavirus Mayhem  5 Bank Stocks to Buy Now Because This Isn't 2008 Again  12 Stocks to Buy That Are Already Positive

title: FRIDAY DEADLINE NOTICE: The Schall Law Firm Announces the Filing of a Class Action Lawsuit Against Netflix, Inc. and Encourages Investors with Losses in Excess of $100,000 to Contact the Firm
content:
LOS ANGELES, Sept.  20, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Schall Law Firm, a national shareholder rights litigation firm, announces the filing of a class action lawsuit against Netflix, Inc. (“Netflix” or “the Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) for violations of §§10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Investors who purchased the Company's shares between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, inclusive (the ''Class Period''), are encouraged to contact the firm before September 20, 2019.

If you are a shareholder who suffered a loss, click here to participate.

We also encourage you to contact Brian Schall of the Schall Law Firm, 1880 Century Park East, Suite 404, Los Angeles, CA 90067, at 424-303-1964, to discuss your rights free of charge. You can also reach us through the firm's website at www.schallfirm.com, or by email at brian@schallfirm.com.

The class, in this case, has not yet been certified, and until certification occurs, you are not represented by an attorney. If you choose to take no action, you can remain an absent class member.

According to the Complaint, the Company made false and misleading statements to the market. Netflix failed to hit its target for new subscribers gained in the second quarter of 2019. The Company also lost subscribers within the United States during the same quarter. Based on these facts, the Company’s public statements were false and materially misleading. When the market learned the truth about Netflix, investors suffered damages.

Join the case to recover your losses.

The Schall Law Firm represents investors around the world and specializes in securities class action lawsuits and shareholder rights litigation.

This press release may be considered Attorney Advertising in some jurisdictions under the applicable law and rules of ethics.

ABIOMED Inc. (NASDAQ: ABMD)

Throughout the Class Period, Defendants made material misstatements and/or failed to disclose that: (i) Abiomed’s revenue growth was in decline; (ii) the Company did not have a sufficient plan in place to stem its declining revenue growth; (iii) the Company was unlikely to restore its revenue growth over the next several fiscal quarters; (iv) consequently, Abiomed was reasonably likely to revise its full-year 2020 guidance in a way that would fall short of the Company’s prior projections and market expectations; and (v) as a result, the Company’s public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

You can review a copy of the Complaints by visiting the links below or you may contact Peretz Bronstein, Esq. or his Investor Relations Analyst, Yael Hurwitz of Bronstein, Gewirtz & Grossman, LLC at 212-697-6484. Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ: NFLX) Class Period: April 17, 2019 - July 17, 2019
Deadline: September 20, 2019
For more info:www.bgandg.com/nflx
The lawsuit alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

Karyopharm Therapeutics Inc. (NASDAQ: KPTI) 
Class Period: March 2, 2017 - February 22, 2019
Deadline: September 23, 2019 For more info:www.bgandg.com/kpti
The lawsuit alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that material adverse information. The complaint continues to allege that Karyopharm hyped the commercial prospects for selinexor and consistently described selinexor as having a “predictable and manageable tolerability profile” and a “very nice safety profile,” and assured shareholders that it was “well tolerated” by patients. The complaint also states that Karyopharm declared that selinexor had the potential to be used as a new treatment for MM, with limited and manageable side effects. As a result of these misrepresentations, Karyopharm shares traded at artificially inflated prices during the Class Period.

title: Deadline Reminder: The Law Offices of Howard G. Smith Reminds Investors of Looming Deadline in the Class Action Lawsuit Against Netflix, Inc.
content:
BENSALEM, Pa., Sept.  12, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Law Offices of Howard G. Smith reminds investors of the upcoming September 20, 2019 deadline to file a lead plaintiff motion in the class action filed on behalf of investors who purchased Netflix, Inc. (“Netflix” or the “Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) securities between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, inclusive (the “Class Period”).

Investors suffering losses on their Netflix investments are encouraged to contact the Law Offices of Howard G. Smith to discuss their legal rights in this class action at 888-638-4847 or by email to howardsmith@howardsmithlaw.com.

On July 17, 2019, after market hours, Netflix disclosed that it only acquired 2.7 million new subscribers, significantly below its forecast of 5 million new subscribers, during second quarter 2019.

On this news, shares of Netflix fell $47.34 per share, or over 13%, over two consecutive trading sessions to close at $315.10 per share on July 19, 2019, thereby injuring investors.

The complaint filed in this class action alleges that throughout the Class Period, Defendants made materially false and/or misleading statements, as well as failed to disclose material adverse facts about the Company’s business, operations, and prospects. Specifically, Defendants failed to disclose to investors: (1) that Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) that Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) that, as a result of the foregoing, Defendants’ positive statements about the Company’s business, operations, and prospects were materially misleading and/or lacked a reasonable basis.

If you purchased Netflix securities during the Class Period you may move the Court no later than September 20, 2019 to ask the Court to appoint you as lead plaintiff if you meet certain legal requirements. To be a member of the class action you need not take any action at this time; you may retain counsel of your choice or take no action and remain an absent member of the class action. If you wish to learn more about this class action, or if you have any questions concerning this announcement or your rights or interests with respect to these matters, please contact Howard G. Smith, Esquire, of Law Offices of Howard G. Smith, 3070 Bristol Pike, Suite 112, Bensalem, Pennsylvania 19020 by telephone at (215) 638-4847, toll-free at (888) 638-4847, or by email to howardsmith@howardsmithlaw.com, or visit our website at www.howardsmithlaw.com.

This press release may be considered Attorney Advertising in some jurisdictions under the applicable law and ethical rules.

title: LEAD PLAINTIFF DEADLINE ALERT: Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP Encourages Investors Who Suffered Losses Exceeding $500,000 Investing In Netflix, Inc. To Contact The Firm
content:
NEW YORK, Sept.  10, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP, a leading national securities law firm, reminds investors in Netflix, Inc. ("Netflix" or the "Company")(NASDAQ: NFLX) of the September 20, 2019 deadline to seek the role of lead plaintiff in a federal securities class action that has been filed against the Company.

If you invested in Netflix stock or options between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019 and would like to discuss your legal rights, click here: www.faruqilaw.com/NFLX. There is no cost or obligation to you.

You can also contact us by calling Richard Gonnello toll free at 877-247-4292 or at 212-983-9330 or by sending an e-mail to rgonnello@faruqilaw.com.

CONTACT:
 FARUQI & FARUQI, LLP 
 685 Third Avenue, 26th Floor 
 New York, NY 10017 
 Attn:  Richard Gonnello, Esq. 
 rgonnello@faruqilaw.com 
 Telephone: (877) 247-4292 or (212) 983-9330

The lawsuit has been filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of all those who purchased Netflix securities between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019 (the "Class Period"). The case, Wallerstein v. Netflix, Inc. et al., No. 19-cv-04195 was filed on July 22, 2019, and has been assigned to Judge Lucy H. Koh.

The lawsuit focuses on whether the Company and its executives violated federal securities laws by failing to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, after the market closed, Netflix released a letter to shareholders which revealed that Netflix missed its expected target for number of new subscribers. The letter to shareholders revealed that Netflix lost 126,000 subscribers in the United States during the second quarter of 2019. On the same day, Netflix held an earnings call to discuss its financial and operating results for the quarter. During the call, the Company’s Chief Financial Officer attributed the missed subscription target to the “timing of [Netflix’s] content slate” and price increases.

On this news, Netflix's share price fell from $362.44 per share on July 17, 2019 to a closing price of $315.10 on July 19, 2019: a $47.34 or 13.06% two-day drop.

The court-appointed lead plaintiff is the investor with the largest financial interest in the relief sought by the class who is adequate and typical of class members who directs and oversees the litigation on behalf of the putative class. Any member of the putative class may move the Court to serve as lead plaintiff through counsel of their choice, or may choose to do nothing and remain an absent class member. Your ability to share in any recovery is not affected by the decision to serve as a lead plaintiff or not.

Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP also encourages anyone with information regarding Netflix's conduct to contact the firm, including whistleblowers, former employees, shareholders and others.

Attorney Advertising. The law firm responsible for this advertisement is Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP (www.faruqilaw.com). Prior results do not guarantee or predict a similar outcome with respect to any future matter. We welcome the opportunity to discuss your particular case. All communications will be treated in a confidential manner.

content:

(“Netflix” or “the Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) for violations of §§10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Investors who purchased the Company's shares between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, inclusive (the ''Class Period''), are encouraged to contact the firm before September 20, 2019.

If you are a shareholder who suffered a loss, click here to participate.

We also encourage you to contact Brian Schall of the Schall Law Firm, 1880 Century Park East, Suite 404, Los Angeles, CA 90067, at 424-303-1964, to discuss your rights free of charge. You can also reach us through the firm's website at www.schallfirm.com, or by email at brian@schallfirm.com.

The class, in this case, has not yet been certified, and until certification occurs, you are not represented by an attorney. If you choose to take no action, you can remain an absent class member.

title: SHAREHOLDER ALERT: Pomerantz Law Firm Reminds Shareholders with Losses on their Investment in Netflix, Inc. of Class Action Lawsuit and Upcoming Deadline – NFLX
content:
NEW YORK, Sept.  05, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Pomerantz LLP announces that a class action lawsuit has been filed against Netflix, Inc. (“Netflix” or the “Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) and certain of its officers. The class action, filed in United States District Court, for the Northern District of California, and indexed under 19-cv-04395, is on behalf of a class consisting of all persons and entities who purchased or otherwise acquired the publicly traded securities of Netflix between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, both dates inclusive (the “Class Period”). Plaintiff seeks to recover compensable damages caused by Defendants’ violations of the federal securities laws and to pursue remedies under Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the “Exchange Act”) and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder.

If you are a shareholder who purchased Netflix securities during the class period, you have until, September 20, 2019, to ask the Court to appoint you as Lead Plaintiff for the class. A copy of the Complaint can be obtained at www.pomerantzlaw.com. To discuss this action, contact Robert S. Willoughby at rswilloughby@pomlaw.com or 888.476.6529 (or 888.4-POMLAW), toll-free, Ext. 9980. Those who inquire by e-mail are encouraged to include their mailing address, telephone number, and the number of shares purchased.

[Click here for information about joining the class action]

Netflix provides Internet entertainment services, primarily streaming services.

The complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, Defendants made materially false and misleading statements regarding the Company’s business, operational and compliance policies. Specifically, Defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (i) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (ii) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (iii) as a result, Defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, post-market, Netflix released a letter to shareholders which revealed that Netflix missed its expected target for number of new subscribers and lost 126,000 subscribers in the United States during the second quarter of 2019. Also on July 17, 2019, Netflix held an earnings call to discuss its financial and operating results for the quarter. During the earnings call, the Company’s Chief Financial Officer attributed the missed subscription target to the “timing of [Netflix’s] content slate” and price increases.

On this news, Netflix’s stock price fell $47.34 per share, or over 13%, over the following two trading sessions, closing at $315.10 per share on July 19, 2019.

The Pomerantz Firm, with offices in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, and Paris, is acknowledged as one of the premier firms in the areas of corporate, securities, and antitrust class litigation. Founded by the late Abraham L. Pomerantz, known as the dean of the class action bar, the Pomerantz Firm pioneered the field of securities class actions. Today, more than 80 years later, the Pomerantz Firm continues in the tradition he established, fighting for the rights of the victims of securities fraud, breaches of fiduciary duty, and corporate misconduct. The Firm has recovered numerous multimillion-dollar damages awards on behalf of class members. See www.pomerantzlaw.com.

CONTACT:
Robert S. Willoughby
Pomerantz LLP
rswilloughby@pomlaw.com

title: LEAD PLAINTIFF DEADLINE ALERT: Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP Encourages Investors Who Suffered Losses Exceeding $500,000 Investing In Netflix, Inc. To Contact The Firm
content:
NEW YORK, Sept.  04, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP, a leading national securities law firm, reminds investors in Netflix, Inc. ("Netflix" or the "Company")(NASDAQ: NFLX) of the September 20, 2019 deadline to seek the role of lead plaintiff in a federal securities class action that has been filed against the Company.

If you invested in Netflix stock or options between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019 and would like to discuss your legal rights, click here: www.faruqilaw.com/NFLX. There is no cost or obligation to you.

You can also contact us by calling Richard Gonnello toll free at 877-247-4292 or at 212-983-9330 or by sending an e-mail to rgonnello@faruqilaw.com.

CONTACT:
 FARUQI & FARUQI, LLP 
 685 Third Avenue, 26th Floor 
 New York, NY 10017 
 Attn:  Richard Gonnello, Esq. 
 rgonnello@faruqilaw.com 
 Telephone: (877) 247-4292 or (212) 983-9330

The lawsuit has been filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of all those who purchased Netflix securities between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019 (the "Class Period"). The case, Wallerstein v. Netflix, Inc. et al., No. 19-cv-04195 was filed on July 22, 2019, and has been assigned to Judge Lucy H. Koh.

The lawsuit focuses on whether the Company and its executives violated federal securities laws by failing to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, after the market closed, Netflix released a letter to shareholders which revealed that Netflix missed its expected target for number of new subscribers. The letter to shareholders revealed that Netflix lost 126,000 subscribers in the United States during the second quarter of 2019. On the same day, Netflix held an earnings call to discuss its financial and operating results for the quarter. During the call, the Company’s Chief Financial Officer attributed the missed subscription target to the “timing of [Netflix’s] content slate” and price increases.

On this news, Netflix's share price fell from $362.44 per share on July 17, 2019 to a closing price of $315.10 on July 19, 2019: a $47.34 or a 13.06% two-day drop.

The court-appointed lead plaintiff is the investor with the largest financial interest in the relief sought by the class who is adequate and typical of class members who directs and oversees the litigation on behalf of the putative class. Any member of the putative class may move the Court to serve as lead plaintiff through counsel of their choice, or may choose to do nothing and remain an absent class member. Your ability to share in any recovery is not affected by the decision to serve as a lead plaintiff or not.

Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP also encourages anyone with information regarding Netflix's conduct to contact the firm, including whistleblowers, former employees, shareholders and others.

Attorney Advertising. The law firm responsible for this advertisement is Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP (www.faruqilaw.com). Prior results do not guarantee or predict a similar outcome with respect to any future matter. We welcome the opportunity to discuss your particular case. All communications will be treated in a confidential manner.

Deadline: September 20, 2019
For more info:www.bgandg.com/nflx
The lawsuit alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

Karyopharm Therapeutics Inc. (NASDAQ: KPTI) 
Class Period: March 2, 2017 - February 22, 2019
Deadline: September 23, 2019 For more info:www.bgandg.com/kpti
The lawsuit alleges that throughout the Class Period, defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that material adverse information. The complaint continues to allege that Karyopharm hyped the commercial prospects for selinexor and consistently described selinexor as having a “predictable and manageable tolerability profile” and a “very nice safety profile,” and assured shareholders that it was “well tolerated” by patients. The complaint also states that Karyopharm declared that selinexor had the potential to be used as a new treatment for MM, with limited and manageable side effects. As a result of these misrepresentations, Karyopharm shares traded at artificially inflated prices during the Class Period.

Class Period: February 28, 2018 - July 16, 2019
Deadline: September 24, 2019
For more info:www.bgandg.com/mnk

The case, Wallerstein v. Netflix, Inc. et al., No. 19-cv-04195 was filed on July 22, 2019, and has been assigned to Judge Lucy H. Koh.

The lawsuit focuses on whether the Company and its executives violated federal securities laws by failing to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, after the market closed, Netflix released a letter to shareholders which revealed that Netflix missed its expected target for number of new subscribers. The letter to shareholders revealed that Netflix lost 126,000 subscribers in the United States during the second quarter of 2019. On the same day, Netflix held an earnings call to discuss its financial and operating results for the quarter. During the call, the Company’s Chief Financial Officer attributed the missed subscription target to the “timing of [Netflix’s] content slate” and price increases.

On this news, Netflix's share price fell from $362.44 per share on July 17, 2019 to a closing price of $315.10 on July 19, 2019: a $47.34 or a 13.06% two-day drop.

The court-appointed lead plaintiff is the investor with the largest financial interest in the relief sought by the class who is adequate and typical of class members who directs and oversees the litigation on behalf of the putative class. Any member of the putative class may move the Court to serve as lead plaintiff through counsel of their choice, or may choose to do nothing and remain an absent class member. Your ability to share in any recovery is not affected by the decision to serve as a lead plaintiff or not.

Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP also encourages anyone with information regarding Netflix's conduct to contact the firm, including whistleblowers, former employees, shareholders and others.

Attorney Advertising. The law firm responsible for this advertisement is Faruqi & Faruqi, LLP (www.faruqilaw.com). Prior results do not guarantee or predict a similar outcome with respect to any future matter. We welcome the opportunity to discuss your particular case. All communications will be treated in a confidential manner.

OmniCell Inc. (NASDAQ: OMCL)

title: SHAREHOLDER ALERT: Pomerantz Law Firm Reminds Shareholders with Losses on their Investment Netflix, Inc. of Class Action Lawsuit and Upcoming Deadline – NFLX
content:
NEW YORK, Aug.  20, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Pomerantz LLP announces that a class action lawsuit has been filed against Netflix, Inc. (“Netflix” or the “Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) and certain of its officers. The class action, filed in United States District Court, for the Northern District of California, and indexed under 19-cv-04395, is on behalf of a class consisting of all persons and entities who purchased or otherwise acquired the publicly traded securities of Netflix between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, both dates inclusive (the “Class Period”). Plaintiff seeks to recover compensable damages caused by Defendants’ violations of the federal securities laws and to pursue remedies under Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the “Exchange Act”) and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder.

If you are a shareholder who purchased Netflix securities during the class period, you have until, September 20, 2019, to ask the Court to appoint you as Lead Plaintiff for the class. A copy of the Complaint can be obtained at www.pomerantzlaw.com. To discuss this action, contact Robert S. Willoughby at rswilloughby@pomlaw.com or 888.476.6529 (or 888.4-POMLAW), toll-free, Ext. 9980. Those who inquire by e-mail are encouraged to include their mailing address, telephone number, and the number of shares purchased.

[Click here for information about joining the class action]

Netflix provides Internet entertainment services, primarily streaming services.

The complaint alleges that throughout the Class Period, Defendants made materially false and misleading statements regarding the Company’s business, operational and compliance policies. Specifically, Defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (i) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (ii) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (iii) as a result, Defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, post-market, Netflix released a letter to shareholders which revealed that Netflix missed its expected target for number of new subscribers and lost 126,000 subscribers in the United States during the second quarter of 2019. Also on July 17, 2019, Netflix held an earnings call to discuss its financial and operating results for the quarter. During the earnings call, the Company’s Chief Financial Officer attributed the missed subscription target to the “timing of [Netflix’s] content slate” and price increases.

On this news, Netflix’s stock price fell $47.34 per share, or over 13%, over the following two trading sessions, closing at $315.10 per share on July 19, 2019.

The Pomerantz Firm, with offices in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, and Paris, is acknowledged as one of the premier firms in the areas of corporate, securities, and antitrust class litigation. Founded by the late Abraham L. Pomerantz, known as the dean of the class action bar, the Pomerantz Firm pioneered the field of securities class actions. Today, more than 80 years later, the Pomerantz Firm continues in the tradition he established, fighting for the rights of the victims of securities fraud, breaches of fiduciary duty, and corporate misconduct. The Firm has recovered numerous multimillion-dollar damages awards on behalf of class members. See www.pomerantzlaw.com.

CONTACT:
Robert S. Willoughby
Pomerantz LLP
rswilloughby@pomlaw.com

title: INVESTOR ACTION ALERT: The Schall Law Firm Announces the Filing of a Class Action Lawsuit Against Netflix, Inc. and Encourages Investors with Losses in Excess of $100,000 to Contact the Firm
content:
LOS ANGELES, Aug.  12, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Schall Law Firm, a national shareholder rights litigation firm, announces the filing of a class action lawsuit against Netflix, Inc. (“Netflix” or “the Company”) (NASDAQ: NFLX) for violations of §§10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 promulgated thereunder by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Investors who purchased the Company's shares between April 17, 2019 and July 17, 2019, inclusive (the ''Class Period''), are encouraged to contact the firm before September 20, 2019.

If you are a shareholder who suffered a loss, click here to participate.

We also encourage you to contact Brian Schall of the Schall Law Firm, 1880 Century Park East, Suite 404, Los Angeles, CA 90067, at 424-303-1964, to discuss your rights free of charge. You can also reach us through the firm's website at www.schallfirm.com, or by email at brian@schallfirm.com.

The class, in this case, has not yet been certified, and until certification occurs, you are not represented by an attorney. If you choose to take no action, you can remain an absent class member.

According to the Complaint, the Company made false and misleading statements to the market. Netflix failed to hit its target for new subscribers gained in the second quarter of 2019. The Company also lost subscribers within the United States during the same quarter. Based on these facts, the Company’s public statements were false and materially misleading. When the market learned the truth about Netflix, investors suffered damages.

Join the case to recover your losses.

The Schall Law Firm represents investors around the world and specializes in securities class action lawsuits and shareholder rights litigation.

This press release may be considered Attorney Advertising in some jurisdictions under the applicable law and rules of ethics.

The Schall Law Firm
 Brian Schall, Esq.,
www.schallfirm.com
Office: 310-301-3335
Cell: 424-303-1964
info@schallfirm.com

The Schall Law Firm

title: Bragar Eagel & Squire, P.C. Reminds Investors That Class Action Lawsuits Have Been Filed Against Netflix, EQT, Eagle Bancorp, and Karyopharm and Encourages Investors to Contact the Firm
content:
NEW YORK, Aug.  11, 2019  (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Bragar Eagel & Squire, P.C. reminds investors that class action lawsuits have been commenced on behalf of stockholders of Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ: NFLX), EQT Corporation (NYSE: EQT), Eagle Bancorp, Inc. (NASDAQ: EGBN), and Karyopharm Therapeutics, Inc. (NASDAQ: KPTI). Stockholders have until the deadlines below to petition the court to serve as lead plaintiff. Additional information about each case can be found at the link provided.

Netflix, Inc. (NASDAQ: NFLX)

Class Period: April 17, 2019 to July 17, 2019

Lead Plaintiff Deadline: September 20, 2019

The complaint, filed on July 22, 2019, alleges that throughout the Class Period defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (1) Netflix would not be able to gain its expected target number of new subscribers in the second quarter of 2019; (2) Netflix would also lose subscribers from the United States in the second quarter of 2019; and (3) as a result, defendants’ public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times. When the true details entered the market, the lawsuit claims that investors suffered damages.

For more information on the Netflix class action go to: https://bespc.com/nflx

EQT Corporation (NYSE: EQT)

Lead Plaintiff Deadline: August 26, 2019

Class Period: June 19, 2017 to October 24, 2018

The Complaint, filed on June 26, 2019, alleges that during the Class Period defendants falsely stated that EQT's acquisition of Rice, a rival gas producer, would yield billions of dollars in synergies based on purported operational benefits. Specifically, on June 19, 2017, defendants announced that EQT had entered into an agreement to acquire Rice for $6.7 billion. Defendants represented that because Rice had an acreage footprint largely contiguous to EQT's existing acreage, the acquisition would allow EQT to achieve "a 50% increase in average lateral [drilling] lengths" (as opposed to more traditional vertical well drilling). EQT claimed that as a result, the merger would result in $2.5 billion in synergies, including $100 million in cost savings in 2018 alone. After the closing in November 2017, the Company continued to tout the "significant operational synergies" of the merger. As a result of defendants' misrepresentations, EQT shares traded at artificially inflated prices throughout the Class Period. On March 15, 2018, just five months after the acquisition closed, EQT announced the sudden and unexpected resignation of its CEO. Then, on October 25, 2018, the Company reported poor third-quarter financial results caused by an increase in total costs and disclosed that its estimated capital expenditures for well development in 2018 would increase by $300 million. As a result, the Company reduced its full year forecast for 2018. These disclosures caused EQT shares to decline by 13%, dropping from a close of $40.46 per share on October 24, 2018 to $35.34 on October 25, 2018.

To learn more about the EQT class action go to: https://bespc.com/eqt

Eagle Bancorp, Inc. (NASDAQ: EGBN)

Lead Plaintiff Deadline: September 23, 2019

Class Period: March 2, 2015 to July 19, 2019

The complaint, filed on July 24, 2019, alleges that throughout the Class Period defendants made materially false and misleading statements regarding the Company’s business, operational and compliance policies. Specifically, defendants made false and/or misleading statements and/or failed to disclose that: (i) Eagle Bancorp’s internal controls and procedures and compliance policies were inadequate; (ii) the foregoing shortcoming created a foreseeable risk of heightened regulatory scrutiny and the need for the Company to undertake its own internal investigations; and (iii) as a result, the Company’s public statements were materially false and misleading at all relevant times.

On July 17, 2019, Eagle Bancorp disclosed rising legal costs stemming from ongoing internal and government investigations of “the Company’s identification, classification and disclosure of related party transactions; the retirement of certain former officers and directors; and the relationship of the Company and certain of its former officers and directors with a local public official.”

On this news, Eagle Bancorp’s stock price fell $14.30 per share, or 26.75%, to close at $39.15 per share on July 18, 2019.

For more information on the Eagle Bancorp class action go to: https://bespc.com/EGBN

Karyopharm Therapeutics, Inc. (NASDAQ: KPTI)

Lead Plaintiff Deadline: September 23, 2019

Class Period: March 2, 2017 to February 22, 2019

The Complaint, filed on July 23, 2019, alleges that during the Class Period defendants falsely represented the safety and efficacy of selinexor, a pharmaceutical drug intended for the treatment of various types of cancer that Karyopharm was in the process of developing. Specifically, defendants' material misrepresentations and omissions center on defendants' claims regarding results from clinical trials for selinexor's treatment of patients with certain types of blood cancer. During the Class Period, defendants claimed that selinexor studies showed that selinexor was "well-tolerated" by patients and explained that there were "no new clinically significant adverse events in the patients receiving selinexor." The Company repeatedly touted the commercial prospects for selinexor and consistently described selinexor as having a "predictable and manageable tolerability profile" and a "very nice safety profile." In reality, selinexor was unsafe with limited efficacy.

The truth was revealed on February 22, 2019, when the Federal Drug Administration ("FDA") released a briefing document that expressed serious concerns with selinexor. Specifically, the FDA revealed that, contrary to Karyopharm's assurances, one of the previously cancelled selinexor trials had resulted in "worse overall survival" for certain patients treated with selinexor, which "highlight[ed] the toxicity of this drug." The FDA unambiguously concluded that "[t]reatment with selinexor is associated with significant toxicity" and has "limited efficacy." These disclosures caused the Company's stock price to decline from $8.97 per share to $5.07 per share, or more than 43%.

For more information on the karyopharm class action go to: https://bespc.com/KPTI

Bragar Eagel & Squire, P.C. is a New York-based law firm concentrating in commercial and securities litigation.  For additional information about Bragar Eagel & Squire, P.C. please go to www.bespc.com.  Attorney advertising.  Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes.
